cards.title: Athletics / Mo Farah looks like the victim of a witch-hunt, says Steve Cram
cards.rawTitle: Mo Farah looks like the victim of a witch-hunt, says Steve Cram

item.title: Mo Farah looks like the victim of a witch-hunt, says Steve Cram
item.trailText: Steve Cram believes Mo Farah is the victim of a witch hunt after the double Olympic champion was forced to deny ever using performance-enhancing drugs
item.standFirst:
• ‘We have gone off on a couple of tangents from the original allegations’
• ‘I can understand why Mo is annoyed,’ former world champion says
item.body:
Steve Cram believes Mo Farah is the victim of a witch-hunt after the double Olympic champion was forced to deny ever using performance-enhancing drugs. Farah issued a statement on Friday defending his reputation in the wake of a BBC investigation that alleged his coach, Alberto Salazar, had practised doping techniques with the American athlete Galen Rupp. It emerged this past week that Farah had missed two drugs tests in the buildup to the 2012 Olympics.

Cram, the 1983 world 1500m champion, told the BBC: “It has begun to look like a bit of a witch-hunt against Mo. It seems as if some people are deliberately going after him and that is a shame.”

Farah won gold in the 5,000m and 10,000m in London three years ago, with Cram commentating on his successes for the BBC. The Panorama documentary about Salazar did not accuse Farah of any wrongdoing but Thursday’s revelations regarding his missed tests led to further questions being asked and Cram sympathised with the 32-year-old. “We have gone off on a couple of different tangents from the original set of allegations,” Cram said. “The allegations were against his coach. Now Mo has also had to come out give an explanation about the two missed tests. We need clarification on that.

“Some sections of the media seem keen to make out that a missed test means avoiding a test, which it does not. There is an individual here being targeted around his credibility as an athlete. In some quarters people are now saying he is a cheat. I can understand why Mo is annoyed and frustrated and all the other words he used in his statement.”

Farah used Facebook to address his missed tests in 2010 and 2011, writing: “I have never taken performance-enhancing drugs in my life and I never will.

“Over the course of my career I have taken hundreds of drugs tests and every single one has been negative. I’ve fully explained the only two tests in my career that I have ever missed, which the authorities understood, and there was never any suggestion that these were anything more than simple mistakes.

“The last two weeks have been the toughest of my life – with rumours and speculation about me that are completely false – and the impact this has had on my family and friends has left me angry, frustrated and upset.”

Salazar has denied the allegations against him, and Farah revealed he had travelled to his base in Portland, Oregon to speak to the American about the allegations. “As I made clear, I went to Portland to speak to Alberto Salazar and demand answers,” Farah added. “He reassured me that the claims are false and that he will soon be providing evidence to make that clear. Until then I will not be commenting further on the allegations.”

Farah is training in France ready for a planned return at the Diamond League meeting in Monaco on 17 July. “Running is the one thing Mo can control at the moment and the one place where he can be Mo Farah and get away from this to some extent,” said Cram, a former world record holder over 1500m and the mile. “It can’t be easy but until something is proved against him we want to see him on track and racing because we don’t have many medal hopes. I bet he can’t wait to get back to racing.”

displayImages.caption: Mo Farah celebrates winning the London 2012 10,000m final with the silver medallist, Galen Rupp. Steve Cram commentated on the race for the BBC. Photograph: Martin Rickett/PA
displayImages.credit: Martin Rickett/PA

cards.title: Rugby league / NRL wrap: Sharks net tight win over Knights
cards.rawTitle: NRL wrap: Sharks net tight win over Knights

item.title: NRL wrap: Sharks net tight win over Knights
item.trailText: Cronulla have twice come back from 10 points down to earn a thrilling 30-28 NRL victory over Newcastle at Hunter Stadium
item.body:
Cronulla have twice come back from 10 points down to earn a thrilling 30-28 NRL victory over Newcastle at Hunter Stadium.

Despite a miracle tapback from Jake Mamo, a vintage performance from skipper Kurt Gidley, and a late rally that wowed the 14,081-strong crowd, the Knights fell just short and copped their ninth loss in their past 10 games.

Newcastle were headed for victory when Mamo produced an incredible tapback from well over the deadball line for Carlos Tuimavave to touchdown and give them a 10-point lead in the 45th minute.

But three tries in the space of seven minutes - coincidentally when Ben Barba was introduced from the bench - quickly turned the match in Cronulla’s favour.

First veteran Luke Lewis wound back the clock when he found space on the wing, before sending the ball infield and then backing up Barba to score in the 51st.

He also copped a high shot from Tariq Sims in the act of scoring that landed the Knights forward on report.

Barba then went through on their trademark outside-inside play in the 54th minute for his first four-pointer in Sharks colours, followed by Jack Bird completing his double with an individual effort in the 58th.

Newcastle set up a grandstand finish when Kade Snowden powered through in the 79th minute, but the Sharks held on to celebrate a highly-entertaining victory.

displayImages.credit: Ashley Feder/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Newcastle Knights Cronulla Sharks

headerImage.caption: Jack Bird tries to break the tackle of Tariq Sims in the Sharks two-point victory over Newcastle. Photograph: Ashley Feder/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Jack Bird tries to break the tackle of Tariq Sims in the Sharks two-point victory over Newcastle.

snap.title: NRL wrap: Sharks net tight win over Knights

image.credit: Ashley Feder/Getty Images
image.altText: Newcastle Knights Cronulla Sharks

cards.title: Snooker / Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
cards.rawTitle: Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match

item.title: Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
item.trailText: Ronnie O’Sullivan has claimed he was offered money to throw a snooker match but turned it down as the risk was not worth taking
item.standFirst:
• Five-times world champion says the risk is not worth taking
• Stephen Lee’s 12-year ban has scared a lot of players, he adds
item.body:
Ronnie O’Sullivan, the five-times world snooker champion, has said he was offered money to throw a match but declined.

Speaking on The Clare Balding Show, which will air on BT Sport and BBC Two this week, O’Sullivan claimed other players did accept bribes in the past but said he believed the problem had been eradicated after Stephen Lee was banned for match-fixing.

O’Sullivan said: “I was offered money once to throw a game but I couldn’t do it. It’s your sport, you love your sport. They smell it anyway. The risk is just not worth taking and I couldn’t live with myself if I got involved in that.”

In 2012 Lee was suspended on match-fixing charges and the former world No5 was subsequently handed a 12-year ban.

Related: Stephen Lee banned from snooker for 12 years for seven match-fixing charges

“I don’t think it’ll go on in snooker any more because they really made an example of Stephen Lee,” O’Sullivan added. “They banned him for 12 years and I think a lot of the guys that were at it, they’re thinking they wouldn’t be able to play snooker ever again.

“So I think it’s been stamped out of snooker now and if anyone was to do it, they know what the consequences are.”

Three weeks ago, the Irish amateur John Sutton was banned for six years after the sport’s world governing body found him guilty of match-fixing and misusing inside information.

The World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association said Sutton’s offences related to suspicious betting on his match against Scotland’s Jamie Burnett in the qualifying stages of the International Championship.

cards.title: US sports / Copa América: Early Higuain goal steers Argentines past Jamaica
cards.rawTitle: Copa América: Early Higuain goal steers Argentines past Jamaica

item.title: Copa América: Early Higuain goal steers Argentines past Jamaica
item.trailText: An early goal from Gonzalo Higuain was enough to give Argentina a 1-0 victory over Jamaica at the Copa America on Saturday and secure their place in the quarter-finals as winners of Group B
item.body:
An early goal from Gonzalo Higuain was enough to give Argentina a 1-0 victory over Jamaica at the Copa América on Saturday and secure their place in the quarter-finals as winners of Group B.

Higuain collected a pass from Angel di Maria in the 11th minute and turned his marker in the box before firing a low shot past Dwayne Miller in the Jamaican goal.

The Argentines looked set for a goal-fest but despite their dominance in possession could not add to their tally in what was Lionel Messi’s 100th appearance for his country.

“We had phases when we were in good form that give us reason for optimism,” said coach Gerardo Martino said. “If we have games that are more like the second half today then evidently we are going to have problems.“

Martino’s side will find out on Sunday who they meet in the next round, as will Paraguay who finished second in the group.

“The important thing was to secure qualification and we did that,” Higuain said. “Now we need to rest mentally and prepare for the quarter-finals which will be very tough.”

Related: Uruguay 1-1 Paraguay | Copa América Group B match report

Argentina’s victory meant Uruguay finished third and will face Chile in the quarter-finals in Santiago next Wednesday.

Meanwhile, Jamaica are eliminated having lost all three of their matches 1-0, though their German coach Winfried Schafer was pleased with their progress.

“I am very proud of my team, we had too much respect for Argentina in the first half, but more courage in the second,” said Schafer. “For us it was a very good tournament, we know what we have to do, now I can build a very good team.”

Once Higuain put them ahead, the Argentines looked certain to win comfortably.

The Napoli striker almost added a second in the 22nd minute but his lob bounced off the top of the crossbar and behind the goal. Di Maria also rattled the crossbar before halftime and Messi came close with a rasping drive that whistled past Miller’s right-hand post.

Argentina controlled the first 45 minutes in terms of possession and shots on goal but seemed to run out of ideas after the break and the match ended with the Jamaicans bombarding the Argentine goal in search of an equaliser.

Messi’s 100th cap will not be remembered as one of the better matches of his glittering career - but at the age of just 27, he becomes only the fifth player from his country to hit triple figures.

displayImages.credit: Alex Reyes/STR/LatinContent/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Argentina Copa America Jamaica Lionel Messi

headerImage.caption: The tight scoreline disguised Argentina’s dominance, with sloppy finishing sparing Jamaica a more one-sided result. Photograph: Alex Reyes/STR/LatinContent/Getty Images
headerImage.altText: Argentina Copa America Jamaica Lionel Messi
headerImage.cleanCaption: The tight scoreline disguised Argentina’s dominance, with sloppy finishing sparing Jamaica a more one-sided result.

snap.title: Argentina 1-0 Jamaica | 2015 Copa América Group B match report

image.credit: Alex Reyes/STR/LatinContent/Getty Images
image.altText: Argentina Copa America Jamaica Lionel Messi

item.title: NRL wrap: Sharks net tight win over Knights
item.trailText: Cronulla have twice come back from 10 points down to earn a thrilling 30-28 NRL victory over Newcastle at Hunter Stadium
item.body:
Cronulla have twice come back from 10 points down to earn a thrilling 30-28 NRL victory over Newcastle at Hunter Stadium.

cards.title: Olympic Games 2016 / GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa
cards.rawTitle: GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa

item.title: GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa
item.trailText: Alex Danson hailed a ‘really professional performance’ by Great Britain after their 2-0 win over South Africa
item.standFirst:
• Reading striker Alex Danson gives Great Britain 12th-minute lead
• Ireland suffer 4-3 World League shootout defeat by China
item.body:
Great Britain’s women are one win away from Olympic qualification after a fifth successive victory at the World League tournament in Valencia.

Two goals in the opening 14 minutes were enough to beat South Africa 2-0. The victory took them into the World League final in Argentina in December but, more importantly, a top-three finish in this tournament will guarantee a spot at the Rio 2016 Games.

The Reading striker Alex Danson scored her third goal of the competition with a clever spin and shot in the 12th minute and then her club-mate Kate Richardson-Walsh’s deflected penalty corner flew in off the underside of the crossbar.

“We are absolutely delighted. It was a really professional performance by the team,” Danson said. “I think the work we do back home puts us in a good position here; fitness is a key thing and we still have a lot left in the legs.”

Great Britain will face the winners of Germany against Spain in Saturday’s semi-final.

Ireland’s hopes of securing automatic Olympic qualification for the first time were cruelly dashed in a 4-3 shootout defeat by China.

Having conceded an early goal, Ireland deservedly equalised through Chloe Watkins with 18 minutes to go and they were denied a winner when Megan Frazer’s goal was disallowed after an umpire’s video referral.

Ayeisha McFerran was put in goal for the shootout and made two saves but, when Nicola Evans missed the chance to win on the last of the five regulation attempts they lost out in the second round of sudden death.

Ireland’s diminishing hopes of reaching Brazil next year rest with them finishing fifth and hoping results at other qualifying competitions later this year go their way.

displayImages.caption: Great Britain's Laura Unsworth, left, challenges Jade Mayne of South Africa during the World League match in Valencia.  Photograph: Manuel Queimadelos Alonso/Getty Images

cards.title: Sailing / Volvo Ocean Race: stage eight

item.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage eight
item.trailText: The best pictures from the eighth leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lisbon in Portugal to Lorient in France.
item.standFirst:
The best pictures from the eighth leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lisbon in Portugal to Lorient in France. The race covers 39,379 nautical miles and will visit 11 ports in 11 countries over nine months.
• More of the best images from the Volvo Ocean Race so far

image.caption: Onboard Dongfeng Race Team as they negotiate heavy wind and heavy sea while approaching the Bay of Biscay Photograph: Yann Riou/Dongfeng Race Team/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
image.credit: Yann Riou/Dongfeng Race Team/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
image.altText: Onboard Dongfeng Race Team as they negotiate heavy wind and heavy sea while approaching the Bay of Biscay
image.cleanCaption: Onboard Dongfeng Race Team as they negotiate heavy wind and heavy sea while approaching the Bay of Biscay

image.caption: Onboard Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing, Louis Sinclair and Simon “SiFi” Fisher pump on the main halyard as the team shakes a reef in the Bay of Biscay Photograph: MKnighton/Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
image.credit: MKnighton/Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image

image.caption: A big wave of water pours over the top of the watch team of Xabi Fernandez, Antonio Cuervas - Mons ‘eti’ and Willy Altadill onboard MAPFRE Photograph: Francisco Vignale/MAPFRE/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
image.credit: Francisco Vignale/MAPFRE/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
image.altText: A big wave of water pours over the top of the watch team of Xabi Fernandez, Antonio Cuervas - Mons 'eti' and Willy Altadill onboard MAPFRE

image.caption: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage in a time of 3 days, 13 hours, 11 minutes and 11 seconds Photograph: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage
image.cleanCaption: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage in a time of 3 days, 13 hours, 11 minutes and 11 seconds
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: One hour, 26 minutes and 35 seconds later the Dongfeng Race Team was the final yacht to arrive in Lorient to finish in seventh place Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: One hour, 26 minutes and 35 seconds later the Dongfeng Race Team was the final yacht to arrive in Lorient to finish in seventh place
